title: 114_hr5876
content: The Act may be cited as the "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" and establishes a website for Congressionally mandated reports. The "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" requires the Director of the Government Publishing Office to establish a website within a year for the public to access electronic copies of all congressionally mandated reports. The website must include citations to the reports' requirements and electronic copies of the reports. The "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" mandates the creation of a website for public access to electronic copies of congressionally mandated reports. The website must provide open access to reports without restrictions and allow for easy retrieval through various search criteria. The website for public access to congressionally mandated reports must include document identification numbers, statute requirements, key words, full text search, and other relevant information specified by the Director of the Government Publishing Office. It should also display the time and date of report submission, provide access within 30 days, and offer permanent electronic access. The website for public access to congressionally mandated reports must include a means for bulk download, publishing of reports by Federal agencies, and a searchable list of reports. The Director of the Government Publishing Office cannot charge a fee or require registration for access to the website. The website required under subsection (a) must be enhanced and updated as necessary to carry out the purposes of this Act. SEC. 3. FEDERAL AGENCY RESPONSIBILITIES. Federal agencies must publish congressionally mandated reports on their website in an open, machine-readable format without restrictions. They must also submit additional information to the Government Publishing Office as required. Guidance on this process must be issued within eight months. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Director of the Government Publishing Office, must issue guidance to agencies on implementing the Act within eight months of its enactment. SEC. 4. REMOVING AND ALTERING REPORTS. A report submitted for publication on the required website can only be changed or removed with the written consent of the chairman of each congressional committee. SEC. 5. RELATIONSHIP TO THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT. The Act does not require disclosure of exempt information under section 552 of title 5, US Code, or mandate the Director of the Government Publishing Office to review reports for redaction. Federal agencies must redact non-public information before submitting congressionally mandated reports for publication. The Act allows federal agencies to withhold information if disclosure would harm protected interests or is prohibited by law. Agencies must identify and justify redactions made in reports for publication. The agency must make efforts to release nonexempt information if full disclosure of a requested record is not possible. This does not require disclosure of information prohibited by law or exempted under section 552(b)(3) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "congressionally mandated report" and "Federal agency." SEC. 7. IMPLEMENTATION. The Act must be implemented within one year of enactment and applies to congressionally mandated reports submitted after that date.
